subject: RE: [junit] Testing Applets
msgSnippet: ... If you are using Internet Explorer on windows, you can create a COM interface to an instance and tell it to load a web page. Sort of like
messageBody:
On Thu, 27 Sep 2001, Eric Vought wrote:
> A next step from there is to get the tests to run in browser VMs without
> human intervention. This is much more tricky, but is possible and I've
> played with the idea some. Most browsers have an (undocumented) mechanism
> whereby you can access their virtual machine without actually loading the
> browser.

If you are using Internet Explorer on windows, you can create a COM
interface to an instance and tell it to load a web page. Sort of like
remote-controlling explorer. You can put javascript in your HTML page
that can call java methods in your applet to run the tests. You can
also create a second applet that can call methods in the applet under
test because they all live in the same address space.

I think you can use a command line option to tell Netscape which page
to load. I know this feature is available on unix.

This way, it should be very similar to actually running the stuff manually.
What I mean is that this will emulate the live environment as much as
possible. However, I am unsure of how to automate the GUI interaction part.
There are some tricky threading issues involved. I think JFCUnit addresses
these issues for swing -- but unfortunately I am using AWT so I cannot
be of much help at the moment.
